utterance: Unidentified Speaker: about we can make the expertise. So this is I think job part is going to convince all of the society to move from one part to the other one. This is these are my two cents.

utterance: David Koweek: There's some evidence that folks aren't so eager to jump industries even when there's opportunities to transition from carbon-rich industries to renewable energy industries and so I think we should be careful about the assumption that just because we try to stand up new industries for carbon removal or renewable energy that folks are going to be on board and wanting to do that. I think it'll require a fair amount of incentives, you know removing incentives and subsidies from fossil fuels and potentially standing them up on zero carbon or negative carbon industries to help that transition.

annotations.Develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an implied existing idea with evidence and reasoning.
annotations.Critical response: The speaker questions an assumption about people's eagerness to transition industries.
annotations.Offer feedback: The speaker provides suggestions for approaching the transition of industries.

utterance: Unidentified Speaker: Yeah sometimes we have to remove them from their comfort zone you know and say hey remove from there you know get out and try.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces a new idea of encouraging people to move out of their comfort zones as a strategy for transitioning industries.
annotations.supportive response: The speaker is expressing agreement or validation for the need to take action, by suggesting a method to encourage industry transition.

utterance: Roger Aines: as long as we're talking about the issues of the more societal aspects of decarbonizing the economy which which I think we should would be a good idea to sort of decide whether or not that's something we we really want to tackle here or if it's more the technological or scientific aspects or to what degree that they they connect in in a way that we could address meaningfully. But I just wanted to throw in that there are clearly social license aspects along the lines we've been talking about in terms of getting buy-in from society.

annotations.process management: The speaker suggests deciding whether to focus on societal or technological/scientific aspects, guiding the meeting's flow.

utterance: Peter Reiners: But one that I've seen that I'm also concerned about and Julia articulated this well in a way I hadn't heard is the mitigation avoidance protestation which actually I find to be common among scientists that we shouldn't even be thinking about these things because it is an avoidance of what we should be doing to reduce emissions in the first place. And at least in the scientific circles that I work in I meet up with a lot of resistance to even seriously talking about many of the fascinating and important and inevitably necessary technologies and science that we're talking about. I'm not sure that that's something we want to focus on here but it's just something that I find to be an obstacle in the circles that I work in.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an existing idea by providing his perspective and experiences regarding the resistance to discussing certain technologies and science.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker identifies a gap in the willingness to discuss certain topics within scientific circles.
annotations.critical response: The speaker is providing a negative evaluation of the resistance he encounters among some scientists towards discussing certain topics.

utterance: Roger Aines: Andrea? You got a thought on this?

utterance: Andrea Hicks: Yeah I mean I think you know there's pathways and technologies of evolution that we've seen throughout society that maybe we don't start with the perfect solution but we start exploring the technologies that we can today to as Greeshma said accelerate our transition to carbon removal. You know it's not that we start with the perfect solution but we start with some of our biggest industries and get them on board to work on their pathways and then sway public opinion.

annotations.Develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas by providing examples and reasoning.
annotations.Acknowledge contribution: The speaker references Greeshma's statement, acknowledging their contribution.
annotations.Supportive response: The speaker is expressing a positive view on transitioning to carbon removal and seems to agree with previous statements.

utterance: Roger Aines: Jane you're you're in the middle of this all the time. Do you have a thought on this?

annotations.encourage participation: This code applies because Roger Aines is inviting Jane to contribute her thoughts to the discussion, encouraging her participation.

utterance: Jane Zelikova: Yeah and this is like literally the fodder for our work. I think something that Peter said really resonated for me which is that the idea of like sort of the the social dimensions of this work and I know that a lot of us here would maybe consider ourselves to be more on the technical expert side and I think what we really need is to be working with social scientists who are really thinking about the societal sort of like how society perceives new technology or new approaches how they gain traction how those perceptions shift over time and like really needing to work with social scientists to formulate our research questions to formulate our research approaches and make sure that the work that we're doing is really grounded in the social dimensions of carbon removal and climate mitigation. So and I think from an and that includes economists that includes folks that are thinking about technology deployment that includes policy makers and folks that work in the policy space more generally. So that's kind of like where I'm landing now that we can't really decarbonize the economy without engaging deeply and meaningfully with the social sciences.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on previous ideas, particularly emphasizing the need for collaboration with social scientists, economists, and policymakers.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker highlights a gap in their current approach by mentioning the need to engage with social scientists.
annotations.clarify goal: The speaker clarifies the goal of needing to engage with social sciences for their work.

utterance: Julia Brown: our experience in the UK from our climate assembly where we got the parliament convened a group of of citizens who represent the diversity at all sorts of in all sorts of ways of the UK population was that that people are more sympathetic to natural solutions like tree planting and peatland restoration and solutions to do with accelerated weathering and things like that then they are to technologies that require us to store CO2 underground where people were quite nervous about the connotations of that and people were were more taken by creating aggregate that stored CO2 that you could put into building materials and things like that.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas by sharing specific experiences and findings from a climate assembly in the UK, providing concrete examples of public perceptions of different carbon removal solutions.
annotations.signal expertise: The speaker is sharing insights based on a specific study or experience they have had access to, indicating their familiarity with certain aspects of societal perceptions of climate change mitigation strategies.

utterance: Rafael Santos: Yeah on this hybrid approaches another example I can give is that we do here in Guelph quite a bit is the production of biochar and then trying to use the biochar to replace coke in steel making. Of course the big challenge is that the coke in steel making has a very particular morphology chemical properties and so on and it's difficult to make a biochar that can directly replace it but that's one big opportunity to decarbonize steel making is take biochar and replace coke.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas by providing a concrete example of a hybrid approach for decarbonization, specifically the production of biochar to replace coke in steel making.
annotations.propose new idea: Although the idea of hybrid approaches has been mentioned, the specific example of using biochar to replace coke in steel making can be considered as introducing a new application or suggestion.

utterance: Andrea Hicks: And Raphael I would expand on that too that if you use waste energy products. utterance: Andrea Hicks: Right so life cycle assessment typically relies on generalized inventories if you don't have particular inventories. So you can think about like anthracite mining right so it's a type of coal in the US. Europe's been a bit ahead of us on all of this in terms of developing the types of databases you use and Ecoinvent is one of the big ones. The US has the US life cycle inventory from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory which has some of the processes but it's missing so you usually need to fill in. And the USDA E-PACT actually has been putting together a lot of the agricultural databases. I mean agriculture is a little bit interesting right because like depending how you produce a kilogram of corn it could be vastly different in terms of things like added amendments water energy. So I mean I think the US is lagging a little bit behind on the actual inventory data to characterize our systems whereas Europe's been doing it for a while.

annotations.develop idea: Andrea is explaining and elaborating on the concept of life cycle assessment and databases.
annotations.signal expertise: Andrea is showing her knowledge on life cycle assessment, databases, and specific examples, indicating her expertise in the area.
annotations.identify gap: Andrea mentions that the US is lagging behind Europe in terms of inventory data to characterize systems.
